Expectation1: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation1: An operator keeps tweaking settings incorrectly, causing noticeable material waste.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: While traveling, only a small vendor known to be kosher-certified is within reach for the next meal.
Story: I stood by the humming press, watching the operator fiddle with the dials again. My job was to keep these machines running smoothly, but lately, I’d spent more time explaining the basics than actually repairing anything. The supervisor expected me to guide the staff, to make sure they understood how to avoid costly mistakes. Yet, every time I tried to correct the operator, he brushed me off, and the waste bin filled with ruined material. My stomach rumbled—a sharp reminder that I hadn’t eaten since dawn. I glanced at my watch. Lunch break was coming, and I’d already scouted the area: only one small vendor nearby, the only one with a kosher certificate in sight. If I left now, I could grab a meal before the line grew. But the operator was about to start another run, and if I didn’t intervene, more material would be wasted. I felt the pressure mounting—my responsibility to the company, my commitment to my faith, both demanding my attention at the same moment. I hesitated, torn between stepping in to help and stepping out to eat.
